summary:
Nancy is the Chief Executive of Families Outside, a national Scottish charity that works solely on behalf of families affected by imprisonment.  Prior to this she worked as an Independent Criminologist, specialising in research on prison policy and comparative criminology.  She received her M. Phil and Ph. D. from the Institute of Criminology at the University of Cambridge and in 2012 was appointed as Visiting Professor at the University of Strathclyde’s Centre for Law, Crime & Justice. 

She was awarded an OBE in the Queen's 2016 New Year's Honours List for services to Education and Human Rights.

Prof. Loucks has conducted extensive research into human rights issues in prison, female and young offenders, prison violence and protests, addiction, suicides and self-harm, violence risk assessment and management, the experience of offenders with learning difficulties and learning disabilities, homelessness amongst ex-prisoners, and the maintenance of prisoners' family ties.  Her work on family issues includes research into family participation in prisoner resettlement, studies of the role of Prison Visitors’ Centres and of the work of Family Contact Officers, research into young parents in prison, consultations with prisoners' families, and international reviews of the literature on needs and services for prisoners’ families and on private family visits.  

Nancy chairs the Board of the International Coalition for Children with Incarcerated Parents and through June 2021 was Secretary General of Children of Prisoners Europe. She co-chaired the Independent Review of the Response to Deaths in Prison Custody in Scotland and the Justice & Care workstream of the Independent Care Review.

📢 Closing soon!
We’re looking for motivated people who are passionate about making a difference for families impacted by imprisonment! Does this sound like you? ✔️ Check out our vacancies for our Support team in the East and apply before Friday 10th May - https://ow.ly/kzJU50RkZk5
Aww, lovely! Wish I’d known - it would have been great to see you both!

Teaching and research are key to the culture change needed to ensure children’s access to justice.

ingestedContentSummary.description: Families Outside is the only national charity in Scotland working to support the families and children of people affected by imprisonment. We are looking for a dynamic, motivated individual with a passion to contribute to the governance of an excellent service for families affected by imprisonment. We are particularly keen to hear from diverse groups of people with skills or experience in any of the following areas: Children & Families Secure care Social Work practice or senior management Law / legal background Senior role in schools / education Organisational development   While not essential, we particularly encourage interest from people with personal experience of a family member’s imprisonment.   If becoming a Trustee is of interest, please submit a short statement outlining your reasons for wanting to join us to admin@familiesoutside.org.uk. Any questions? Please ring us on 0131 557 9800 – and thank you!   Closing date: Friday, 19 April 2024

Do any of my lovely Linked In colleagues have suggestions for where to get financial support (or support in kind) for international travel?

I have two incredible opportunities to reach global audiences this year (a plenary slot at the ICPA annual conference in Singapore and a Symposium in Kampala to support the development of an African Coalition for Children with Incarcerated Parents). Unfortunately, no funding is available for either. 

Your guidance is very welcome! Thanks in advance -

ingestedContentSummary.description: Join us for the INCCIP Webinar Series: My Story, My Way, where inspiring individuals share their story of having a parent in prison
ingestedContentSummary.fullText: Raised by a single mother in Miami, Florida, on the outskirts of Liberty City. Chynna studied Event Management and Political Science with a minor in Business at the University of Florida. A proud Florida gator, Chynna’s time at UF helped her to gain exposure to event management as a White House intern during the Obama administration. Upon graduation, Chynna spent years supporting the Obama’s advance logistical teams until leaving her administrative role at The Walt Disney Company to ultimately become the “body-woman” of former First Lady Michelle Obama. In this capacity, Chynna helped Mrs. Obama connect with communities around the world. She ensured every detail of Mrs. Obama’s personal and public facing events were executed flawlessly, directing teams who coordinated Mrs. Obama’s domestic and international engagements. At the conclusion of the Obama administration, Chynna was retained by the personal office of Barack and Michelle Obama as their Director of Travel and Event Operations, where she continued to help manage the personal obligations of their family while continuing to oversee the coordination of Mrs. Obama’s engagements. Now at Matriarch Made Development, Chynna helps leaders build core competencies such as but not limited to organization, teamwork, communication, problem solving, accountability and composure in administrative and executive teams. From executive training and coaching to equipping organizations with tools such as scheduling systems, templates, tactics, processes/procedures, events logistics guidance; Matriarch Made helps leading organizations build a systems approach to tackling the inefficiencies that stifle overall potential. Chynna was most recently highlighted in Michelle Obama’s newly released book, “The Light We Carry.” She has written for O Magazine; been featured in Essence, the Miami Herald, the Netflix Documentary “Becoming,” the Michelle Obama Spotify Podcast and more.
ingestedContentSummary.title: INCCIP Webinar Series: My Story, My Way

commentary.text: I took part in this a number of years ago and really got a lot out of it. So pleased ESS is running it again!
Hamed Farmand that’s absolutely on the list, Hamed! Donations of frequent flyer miles or plane tickets work well too 🙂

Lovemore Chikwanda you may indeed! The founder of the International Coalition for Children with Incarcerated Parents (INCCIP) runs a Study Week every year at the Wells of Hope school just outside Kampala. This year, the Study Week runs from 14-19 July, with the 19th of July devoted to an International Symposium to develop an African Coalition. We already have Canadian, Latin American, and European networks, so this is an effort to create a network of support, learning, and shared practice for the many people in African countries who work on this issue.

The INCCIP newsletter contains updates about this event, along with many other news items. Wouid you like be to add you to the mailing list so you can keep up to date?
